ยง1. Cosheaves

Proof. By Exercise 3 it suffices to show that

\[\Gamma_c(\mathcal{L}|U \cap V) \to \Gamma_c(\mathcal{L}|U) \oplus \Gamma_c(\mathcal{L}|V) \to \Gamma_c(\mathcal{L}|U \cup V) \to 0\]

is exact for \(U, V\) open, since part (b) of that exercise clearly holds for \(\mathcal{A} = \Gamma_c\mathcal{L}\). But this follows from the Mayer-Vietoris sequence (27) on page 94. \(\square\)

Now we wish to prove the converse of 1.6. Let \(\mathcal{A}\) be a flabby cosheaf and let \(A\) be the presheaf defined by \(A(U) = \mathcal{A}(X)/\mathcal{A}_{X-U}(X)\), where

\[\mathcal{A}_{B}(X) = \{s \in \mathcal{A}(X) | |s| \subset B\}.\]

Let \(\mathcal{A} = \mathcal{M}ech(A)\). Note that

\[\mathcal{A}_x = \mathcal{A}(X)/\mathcal{A}_{X-\{x\}}(X).\]

There is the canonical map

\[\theta : \mathcal{A}(X) \to \mathcal{A}(X).\]

Clearly, \(\theta(s)(x) = 0 \iff |s| \subset X - \{x\}\). Thus \(|\theta(s)| = |s|\), and in particular, \(\theta\) maps \(\mathcal{A}(X)\) into \(\Gamma_c(\mathcal{A})\) monomorphically. We shall show that \(\theta\) maps onto \(\Gamma_c(\mathcal{A})\).

1.7. Lemma. Let \(U \subset X\) be open and let \(t \in \mathcal{A}(U)\). Suppose that \(s_1, s_2 \in \mathcal{A}(X)\) are given such that \(\theta(s_1)|U_i = t|U_i\) for some open sets \(U_i \subset U\), \(i = 1, 2\). If \(V_i\) is any open set with closure in \(U_i\), \(i = 1, 2\), then there exists an element \(s \in \mathcal{A}(X)\) such that \(\theta(s)|(V_1 \cup V_2) = t|(V_1 \cup V_2)\).

Proof. Since \(|s_1 - s_2| = |\theta(s_1 - s_2)| = |\theta(s_1) - \theta(s_2)|\) is contained in \(X - (U_1 \cap U_2)\), it is also contained in \((X - \overline{V_1}) \cup (X - \overline{V_2})\). Since \(\mathcal{A}\) is a cosheaf, there exist elements \(t_i \in \mathcal{A}(X)\), \(i = 1, 2\), with \(|t_i| \subset X - \overline{V_i}\) and with \(s_1 - s_2 = t_1 - t_2\). Let \(s = s_1 - t_1 = s_2 - t_2\). Then

\[\theta(s)|V_i = \theta(s_i)|V_i = t|V_i,\]

for \(i = 1, 2\), as claimed. \(\square\)

1.8. Proposition. Every flabby cosheaf \(\mathcal{A}\) has the form \(\mathcal{A} = \Gamma_c\mathcal{A}\) for a unique \(c\)-soft sheaf \(\mathcal{A}\). Moreover, the sheaf \(\mathcal{A}\) is torsion-free \(\iff |ms| = |s|\) for all \(s \in \mathcal{A}(X)\) and all \(0 \neq m \in L\). (In this case, we say that \(\mathcal{A}\) is "torsion-free.")
